text_clean_combined: The next witness is Mr. John Ossowski.

text_clean_combined: Morning.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Morning.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Morning.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Mr. Ossowski, will you swear on a religious document, or do you wish to affirm?

text_clean_combined: Affirm, please.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

speaker: THE REGISTRAR

text_clean_combined: John Ossowski. J-O-H-N O-S- S-O-W-S-K-I.

text_clean_combined: --- MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI, Affirmed:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: --- EXAMINATION-IN-CHIEF BY MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE:
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning, Ms. Ossowski. Nice to see you again. My name is Alexandra Heine. I'm Commission Counsel, and I'll be doing your examination today. And at the end, my colleague, Gord Cameron, will have a few questions for you. So we're just going to start by pulling up your witness statement, which, Mr. Clerk, is WTS00000046. Thank you. So you recall that you participated in an interview with Commission Counsel in anticipation of your appearance here today on August 24th?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I do.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And three of your colleagues, Christine Derosiers, Scott Harris and Ted Gallivan, who are not here today, were also interviewed; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so I would ask you to confirm that you've reviewed the summary of that interview, and if you have no changes to make, confirm that insofar as it contains your information, it is accurate to the best of your knowledge and belief and you adopt it, and insofar as it contains information from your colleagues, you believe that information to have been reviewed and accepted as accurate by your colleagues?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I confirm that.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Thank you. So, Mr. Clerk, if we could also pull up DOJ-IR0000006? So, Mr. Ossowski, your department prepared and filed with the Commission this institutional report. Have you reviewed this document?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I have.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And is it accurate to the best of your knowledge and belief?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: It is.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Can you confirm that CBSA has filed this institutional report as part of its evidence before the Commission?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Thank you. So at the time of the Freedom Convoy events, you were the President of the CBSA; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And the CBSA is the Canada Border Services Agency?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So you left that role in June of 2022 I understand?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct. I retired.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. You're retired now. And CBSA manages 117 land border crossings, 22 of which are commercial ports of entry; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And amongst other things, CBSA is responsible for administering and enforcing legislation that governs the admissibility of people and goods in and out of Canada ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Amongst ---
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: -- amongst 90 pieces of legislation and regulation, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. It also identifies detaining and removing people who are inadmissible to Canada?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And ensure compliance with Canadian laws in the border-related context?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And it also protects food and safety, plant and animal health, and Canada's resource base; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And Border Services officers, which are sometimes called BSOs, carry out some of those responsibilities; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And BSOs have regulatory authorities under the Quarantine Act, the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and the Customs Act; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: They have -- well, if there was something happened with respect to the Quarantine Act, if there was something that officers suspected was offside, they would refer that to a Public Health official for how they would decide to enforce that particular provision.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And I understand that BSOs don't have authorities beyond sort of the confines of ports of entry or CBSA property; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct. They're not peace officers. They have very limited Criminal Code powers under the Customs Act and the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So they wouldn't have the power or authority to conduct an arrest, for example, outside of the port of entry?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No. Well, in the case of an immigration enforcement inland, they might ---
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: --- yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: But otherwise ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: But not -- otherwise, no.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And so accordingly, the CBSA doesn't typically intervene in activities that occurs outside of its port of entry and its property; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So in the case of the convoy, the CBSA did not intervene directly in the protest and blockades because they happened near the ports of entry and not on the ports of entry's property; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So on that note, I'll take you through the convoy, and the way I'm going to structure this is I'm going to start by asking you questions about CBSA's response to the convoy and specific blockades, and then I'm going to ask you more specifically later in the examination about your roles and responsibilities during the convoy. Thank you. So we'll start with CBSA's response to the convoy. I understand that on January 25th -- sorry, January 15th, there were certain Order in Council provisions that had previously allowed foreign national truckers to enter Canada unvaccinated that expired; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And on the same day, Canadian unvaccinated commercial truckers entering Canada became subject to testing and quarantine requirements for which they had previously been exempt?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So this caused the sporadic protest activities and ultimately the movement that we know as the Freedom Convoy; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I assume so.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And CBSA had intelligence, mostly open source intelligence, that there were going to be some blockades near ports of entry sometime in late January; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, we certainly saw the first slow roll activity on January 17th in Emerson.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And that slow roll did not become a blockade; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Not yet, no.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. That came later?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And in response to sort of this intelligence, CBSA put into place a contingency plan. Did you have any involvement in that?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That would have been put together by the operational folks in the field with the supervision of the leadership in Ottawa, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. But you knew about it?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And that was on January 28th, I believe; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Amongst other things, I don't think we need to pull it up, I'll just note for the record that it's PB.NSC.CAN.9523, but it identified the safety and security of CBSA employees as its top priority. Is that consistent with your recollection?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And it also provided regions and headquarters with high-level contingency awareness and guidance on CBSA’s operational posture?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And it also set out a process whereby BOC, which is the Border Operations Centre, would provide situational reports twice a day. Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And my colleague, Gord Cameron, is going to touch on that, so he’ll pick it up later, but I understand that CBSA, in addition to the contingency plan, also implemented different port hardening measures?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Can you describe what those measures were?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: It would vary by port of entry, but certainly one of the things that we started to do was, and very unusually, apply cameras facing back into Canada so that we could be aware of what was coming from behind. Obviously the officers are facing the United States. We have lots of cameras facing vehicles and passengers coming into the country. But this was done so they had situational awareness of what might be coming at them from the Canadian side.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Anything else?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Not -- that was probably the most significant piece that we started to do.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And cameras, you mean CCTV, ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- like surveillance footage? Okay. And I understand that BSOs were also instructed, and that’s, again, border services officers, BSOs, were instructed to refer foreign nationals entering Canada for the purpose of participating in protests to secondary for confirmation of their eligibility to enter Canada? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes. It was called the Enhanced Vigilance Exam.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Enhanced Vigilance Exam. And can you explain what sending somebody to secondary means?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: It means that either they declared something during the primary inspection during the initial interaction with an officer where the officer suspected they weren’t being truthful and they went to secondary for a complete exam to make sure that they were eligible to enter the country.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. So if a BSO suspected that somebody wanted to come into Canada to participate in the protest, they would send them to secondary?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And BSOs were also instructed to closely examine those travellers to ensure -- and travellers generally, to ensure the requirements issued by the Public Health Agency of Canada under the Quarantine Act were met by the individuals entering Canada? Is that also right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So that would involve questions about sort of, you know, their vaccination status, testing for covid? Things like that?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah. Proof of vaccination.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So I’ll take you to January 29th, which is when the Coutts blockade started. So that was sort of the first major blockade? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And understanding that there was sporadic protest activities, so specifically slow roll convoys at other ports of entry in late January/early February, I understand that the next major blockade happened at the Bluewater Bridge, which is in Sarnia in Ontario, on February 6th. Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And that blockade dispersed on February 8th?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And then the next major blockade happened in Windsor on February 7th? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s right.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And that’s when CBSA issued its first border alert?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Which advised people that the Ambassador Bridge Port of Entry was experiencing delays? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And specifically experiencing service disruptions?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So could you explain, first, what’s a border alert and what is, second, what is a service disruption, as opposed to a service suspension and a closure of a port of entry?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Sure. So a border alert is just something that we would have sent out to the travelling public or to the commercial side so that they’re aware that they might need to choose another port of entry to come into the country. service disruption just means that for some reason the port of entry isn’t accessible, and/or there’s some -- it could be an IT outage, for example, if there’s a disruption, or it could be that there’s an excessive backlog of traffic. We try to maintain a 60-minute service standard, no longer than 60- minute border wait time. And if that’s not the case, then we’d send out an alert for traveling public and commercial entities to know.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And a port of entry closure, I understand, doesn’t happen very often? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And in what circumstances would that happen?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Like maybe -- very -- I don’t remember we actually closed the port of entry, except for a very short period of time, for example around flooding in Manitoba.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: But we would -- we actually had the ability to suspend service at a port of entry. This is what actually happened in Coutts at the request of the RCMP.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And we’ll get to that. But a service suspension, what does that look like on the ground?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: So the officers are still there, but they’re not processing vehicles or people anymore, except in exceptional circumstances. So you might have the situation where you’re not providing the service but if somebody came and there was a need for an emergency vehicle to get across, then they would facilitate that.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. It’s sort of a skeleton crew that’s sort of at the port of entry just ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. And maybe let’s pull up the Institutional Report. And that’s DOJ.IR.00000006. And Mr. Clerk, if we could go to page 32, please? All right. So this is a chart that sets out the service disruptions and suspensions that occurred sort of at the major ports of entry during the convoy? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And we see that there was a service disruption, as I mentioned earlier, issued on February 7th for Ambassador Bridge?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: M’hm.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And the next service disruption was issued on February -- sorry, service suspension was issued on February 12th? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And there was also a service disruption at Coutts on February 10th as well? Sorry, -- -
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Emerson.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- Emerson. Thank you. And on February 12th, if we just scroll down a bit, there was also a service disruption issued for the Pacific Highway Port of Entry, which is in B.C.? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. So there’s a total of three disruptions and one suspension at those ports of entry?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Were any other service disruptions or suspensions issued for any other ports of entry?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Not that I’m aware of.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Can you walk us through, generally, in terms of border wait times and the like? What were the impacts on these main blockades? The impacts of the blockades on these main ports of entry?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Certainly. So as you mentioned in your opening remarks, there’s 117 land ports of entry. Twenty-two (22) of them are designated commercial ones. And they are specifically set up to receive and process commercial traffic, including livestock and/or time sensitive goods that need to sort of pass expeditiously. Often they’ll have the presence of a CAF food inspector. And importantly, it's set up with our friends to the south in terms of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection. They would have a similar processing capability to mirror the Canadians at those ports of entry. So for example, Coutts is the only designated port of entry that does commercial processing in the Province of Alberta, and the next available one would have been either in Saskatchewan or in British Columbia. There were other ports of entry, but they weren’t designed or set up to process commercial traffic, which is what made it so impactful.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And so let’s go to Coutts in terms of specifics. So as you mentioned, there’s some commercial ports of entry neighbouring Coutts in Saskatchewan and B.C., but I understand that those are eight -- around eight hours away from Coutts? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: It’s quite a drive, yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Not feasible in the winter, especially with livestock.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And those are North Portal in Saskatchewan, or Regway, and Roosville in B.C. or Kingsgate? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe Kingsgate, but I don’t have the list in front of me.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. I think you can just take my word for it.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Sure.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so the CBSA, I understand, in response to the convoy, and because those alternative commercial ports of entry were so far away, they identified Del Bonita and Carway, which are two ports of entry that are closer to Coutts, much closer, Del Bonita is about 50 minutes away and Carway is about an hour and a half away, as potential alternative ports of entry. But as you noted, they were not outfitted to necessarily process commercial traffic? Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Absolutely. So we would have redistributed officers to help with any traffic that chose to go those routes. But they’re not set up, for example, if we had to do an enforcement action, there’s no facility there to offload the vehicle and inspect it completely. So there -- they just weren’t set up to deal with that type of full commercial operation.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And they don’t have infrastructure either, like Canada Food Inspection Agency set up there?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And no USDA veterinary services for livestock.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Exactly.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And so, I understand that in response to these obstacles, Brad Wozny, who is your colleague -- was your colleague, and he’s the Regional Director of the Prairie Region, which captures both Manitoba and Alberta, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: The Regional Director General, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Regional Director General, thank you. And so he worked with the RCMP, which was the local police of jurisdiction in Coutts, the US Custom Border Protection Services, and CFIA, so that’s the Canada Food Inspection Agency, and the US Department of Agriculture, to facilitate the movement of commercial traffic through those alternative ports of entry.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So that’s specifically Del Bonita and Carway. And as he explained in his witness summary, which for the record it’s WTS000000044, they arrange for traffic moving southbound, so that’s going from Canada into the US, to effectively move across to Sweet Grass, Montana, which is located South of Coutts, and access a USDA Inspection Services there, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so then they would be able to, sort of, divert the traffic in that manner. And then the northbound vehicles, so those going from the US into Canada, would drive up to Sweet Grass, and they were inspected by CFIA, and their loads were sealed, and then they would move across to Del Bonita and enter Canada in that way.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so I understand that there were impacts to the Coutts port of entry all the way until February, around February 13th, where there was some enforcement action by the RCMP, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And can you explain sort of what that enforcement action entailed?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: The RCMP arrested four individuals and laid criminal charges.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And there were guns and ammunitions that were seized?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And the rest of the protesters that were remaining agreed to leave sometime midday, or in the afternoon of February 14th, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And if we can pull up, Mr. Clerk, PBCAN1385. (SHORT PAUSE)
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: So, Mr. Ossowski, this is an email that you sent to Minister Mendicino, who’s the Minister of Public Safety, on February 15th, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes, it is.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And you advised him that protestors were leaving Coutts as of 3:00 p.m. on February 14th?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And that around 8:30 p.m., the CBSA was advised that the RCMP had removed the conveyances blocking the lanes and had been able to secure the area, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And you also advised Minister Mendicino that the CBSA was in a position to open the Coutts POE on the next day.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Sorry; on that day, on February 15th.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay, so we’ll move on to Ambassador Bridge. So Ambassador Bridge, the blockades start on February 7, and a service disruption was issued on that day. And then if we can pull up the Institutional Report again, Mr. Clerk, so DOJIR00000006. And if we could go to page 38, please? So this is a chart that was provided to us by the CBSA that shows the commercial conveyances volume from January 15th to February 25th at the Ambassador Bridge, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes, it is.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Can you walk us through the chart, sort of from February 8th to February 13th, and just explain to us what those numbers mean?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, as you can see from the preceding days and it’s -- there’s a very sort of predictable weekly pattern here in terms of the movement of goods, so obviously less on the weekends, and more as you build towards the end of the week. So, for example, February 1st, on Tuesday, we had 4,982 commercial conveyances, so that’s the truck and trailer across the border, and on February 8th as a result of the disruption, five passages were recorded.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And then if we go to February 13th, for example, we see that there’s zero commercial conveyances that passed on that day?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so, Mr. Clerk, if we could just scroll down. So traffic -- yes, keep going. Thank you. So traffic from the Ambassador Bridge was diverted to Blue Water Bridge, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Which is approximately two hours away from the Ambassador Bridge?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And, also, traffic was diverted to Queenston?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Which is further; I believe it’s four hours away, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah, it’s about 400 kilometres away.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And it was also diverted to the Peace Bridge, which is about four hours and 30 minutes away, is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so if we look at this chart again, we see that from February 7th to February 13th, which were the days that the blockade was impacting on the Ambassador Bridge, we see that Blue Water Bridge has sort of absorbed the traffic that would’ve normally gone through Ambassador Bridge; is that fair?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I would disagree with that. So the difference is -- if you look at, again, the Tuesday before, the Blue Water Bridge processed 2,800 vehicles and there was 2,000 more vehicles on February 8th, so that’s only part of what would have normally gone through at the Ambassador Bridge.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And the other part would have presumably gone through Peace Bridge which, if we scroll down, we see that Peace Bridge also has an elevated amount of commercial conveyances on those days.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, again, if you look at the numbers, the difference is only about 250. So it’s not the 5,000 or so that would have normally come through on that day.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And there was also some traffic that was absorbed by Queenston.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes, again, but if you do the math, it wasn’t fully absorbed in terms of what would normally pass at the Ambassador Bridge. And I think the important part to remember here is even though they might have gotten across, it depends on the nature of what they were bringing across. If it was for the auto sector, driving four hours away, and then coming back another four hours would’ve had impact, and it obviously did. And certainly for livestock, it would’ve been not feasible to do something like that either. So it really depended on the load, but if you do the math, there was not a complete replacement, despite the fact that these other ports of entry were potentially available for them to use.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So was CBSA tracking what happened to those commercial vehicles?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: They weren’t -- no? Okay.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No. We just -- we just simply tracked the passages through our systems.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So, it’s possible that those vehicles went home; it’s also possible that they entered in a different manner?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. Thank you. So is it fair to say that most of the commercial vehicle traffic was successfully diverted to neighbouring ports of entry, but not all of it?

text_clean_combined: Right.

text_clean_combined: Right.

text_clean_combined: But it’s less so in southern Ontario.

speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So a resource diversion ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.

text_clean_combined: Absolutely. So I think it's closer to 200 kilometres away from Ambassador Bridge to the Bluewater Bridge. The Bluewater Bridge has 7 commercial lanes compared to the Ambassador's 15. You know, given the fact that processing time takes the same, you're trying to squeeze more volume through a smaller sort of sieve, if you will. And at one point, I heard reports that the traffic lineup was 10 kilometres long at the Bluewater Bridge. So that had a significant impact.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And there was a significant, or a specific impact on the automobile industry; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Absolutely, just because of the just in time manufacturing sector in southern Ontario where the whole process is set up to not have inventory on hand, but have it delivered as it's required, so it's very finely tuned.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And the Ambassador Bridge blockade was cleared up on February 13th as a result of enforcement action; is that right?

text_clean_combined: Right. Overall, would you say that the CBSA responded well to these blockades?

text_clean_combined: I was very proud of the way the organization responded to it. And obviously, some suffered more severe disruptions than others, but it really kept us on our toes in terms of trying to anticipate and work with our American colleagues and the local police of jurisdiction to make sure that we continue to manage the border effectively.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And CBSA took -- you'd say took active steps to mitigate the impacts?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Absolutely.

speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: --- working with their U.S. colleagues, so they could understand what they might need to do in terms or reallocating their resources. So it was a very busy time.

So we see here at the bottom that it says: "The prime minister asked for an update on other POEs and what is being done to prevent further disruptions. The minister of public safety and president of CBSA --- " --- that was you --- "--- confirmed that there is real-time reporting in all critical POEs and ongoing engagement with local law enforcement. If an authority or asset gap is identified, departments remain ready to respond. Currently, it remains only three blocked POEs. There was an attempt to block the Pacific Highway, but police successfully thwarted this attempt." So I have a couple of questions about this. What was meant by "if an authority or asset gap is identified, departments remain ready to respond"?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, just whatever we had within our authority to sort of deal with the situation and collectively with respect to all of the partner departments. You know, I was just -- I don’t recall seeing this language before, but I would say that I was referring to the fact that we were looking collectively as deputy ministers at the time in terms of any authorities or asset gaps to resolve the situation.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And when you say "Currently, it remains only the three blocked POEs" -- this is on February 12th, so which ports of entry are you referring to here?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: It's current in my report here, so I think it would have been the Ambassador Bridge, Emerson ---
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And presumably Coutts?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes, Coutts.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So Emerson, Ambassador Bridge, Coutts.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: It's on page 54 of our institutional report, all of the disruptions on February 12th.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right, thank you. And then if we can go to SSM.CAN.00000095? While that’s being brought up, Mr. Ossowski, this is the February 13th IRG meeting minutes.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Mr. Clerk, we'll just go down to page 5. So the prime minister asked the minister of public safety to outline additional actions that could be taken by federal authorities to deal with and prevent further blockades. Do you recall this?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And the minister of public safety explained that great progress had been made in clearing and securing the Ambassador Bridge, but that there was no definitive timeline for reopening?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And but as we established earlier, the Ambassador Bridge was reopened the next day?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And he also noted that enforcement actions were occurring in Coutts and Emerson. Do you recall this?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And lastly, that -- and we'll skip the part about Ottawa -- at the Blue Water Bridge crossing, the CBSA had also doubled its capacity for commercial vehicles, allowing carriers additional corridors for cross- border trade; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And that was in response to the Ambassador Bridge blockade?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So that was the update that Minister Mendicino provided. Did you also contribute anything to this meeting?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Generally at these meetings I would have provided any situational updates in terms of what was happening at ports of entry and/or what we might have gathered in terms of potential disruptions that would be happening in the near future.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And when Minister Mendicino gives an update like this, is the information that he's conveying information that you have briefed him up on ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- in the context of your daily touching base?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah, we would have, and/or reports that we would have shared with the minister's office and public safety, as well as other departments.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And what kind of reports were those?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: We provided a number of different reports, situational update reports, called the BLUFF reports, Bottom Line Upfront reports that were very real time in nature.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And the Border Operations Centre Situational reports that we talked about earlier, those as well?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So those were sent to both Minister Mendicino's office and public safety?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. I'd like to now ask you questions about the invocation of the Emergencies Act, and sorry, the decision to invoke the Emergencies Act. So earlier, we talked about how you and some of the other deputy ministers discussed alternative authorities that could be used; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And in one of your deputy minister briefing talking point packages, which I understand are binders prepared for you either for DMOCCs or IRGs; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: We don’t need to pull it up, but the reference for the record is SSM.NSC.CAN321. And so that briefing package said that the CBSA considered various avenues of deterrence so the NEXUS trusted trader status of a commercial driver, cancellation of FAST applications, and other options. This is not the first time that those options had been raised; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: It was not the first time or ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I don't think it was the first time, no.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right, because this was February 13th, and if we go to February 10th, which actually, we will pull this one up. So this is an email from Mike Jones, who is Minister Mendicino's chief of staff; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: To Mike Maka from Transport, Samantha Khalil from PMO, and Zita, who is Bill Blair's chief of staff; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And she says: "I've received these enforcement options from CBSA which I've asked for more context around. I understand that it is part of a broader effort to provide options to the clerk. I'm tracking down from my side and Z is going to check in with the NSIA." So the clerk here would be the clerk of the Privy Council; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I would assume so.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And then he goes on to list some of the options that we just talked about, so the Trusted Trader Program, Trusted Traveller Program, NEXUS, and others. Do you know whatever happened to those deterrent options that you put on the table?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, I think we ended up dismissing the Trusted Trader Programs because these are administered bilaterally with the United States, and so we just weren’t sure that we could do something very expeditiously here in terms of what's referenced above as the Good Tariff or clause for these purchase events in the program and try and leverage that so that we would -- they would be aware that there was consequences for their participation in the protest. And then as well, the designated international trade corridors, there, I think, I would just point out that ports of entry up until the invocation of the EMA and the regulations was not a critical infrastructure, and certainly the trade corridors, the highways, were not federal, they also are provincial responsibilities. And so the designation of the routes to and from the ports of entry were an important aspect.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. Right. So the EMRs designated the ports of entry and the trade corridors as critical infrastructure?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And we won't pull it up, pursuant to section 6, made those exclusion zones. Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So ultimately none of these options ever went anywhere?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, except for the trade corridor piece.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. Because of the Emergencies Act. I mean prior to the Emergencies Act.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And did you play a role in the decision to invoke the Emergencies Act?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I simply provided advice from the CBSA perspective in terms of managing the corridor.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Can you elaborate on that?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, the one thing, we identified a gap in the sense that as we were starting to get to the point of declaring the protest a prohibited protest, that there was no ability for us to stop people from coming in and foreign nationals from coming in and participate in that protest if they were otherwise able to enter. So they met all the other program requirements, the Quarantine Act requirements, whatever else may be involved, but we identified that as a gap.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And when you say "we identified" you mean you reported it to Cabinet?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, through -- first through, obviously, through the deputy minister ---
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: --- colleagues and then ultimately to Cabinet, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. But you were not asked for your advice on invoking the Emergencies Act ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- or directly for your input?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So you never advised any of the Cabinet members whether they should or should not invoke the Emergencies Act?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so you just identified this legislative gap to Cabinet. And you've explained that the gap was that there was no authority to turn somebody away in relation to wanting to participate in a lawful protest; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Correct. I was surprised to know at that time that we couldn't do that, that a foreign national could enter the country for the purpose of participating in a protest.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And the CBSA was concerned with this legislative gap in allowing foreign nationals to come into the country to participate in a peaceful protest?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, I think collectively, when you look at the tools that we were discussing, at that point in time we were trying to de-energise the situation, and obviously allowing people to continue to come into the country for the purpose of participating in a protest was inconsistent with that.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And was it your understanding that many U.S. or foreign nationals were coming into the country to participate in the protest?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, certainly, as part of the enhanced vigilance exam process that we invoked before the Emergencies Act, we turned away people that intended to come and participate in a protest or we suspected were going to participate in a protest, but it was only because they weren't vaccinated or didn't meet up with some other program legislation requirement.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So they would go to secondary and be turned away because they didn't meet the requirements of the Quarantine Act, for example.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. Did the CBSA consider whether they had the authority to turn away foreign nationals on the basis that they wanted to participate in an unlawful protest?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I don't quite understand the question because, like, it's not a prohibition on entry under the Immigration Refugee Protection Act to come and participate in a protest. So what the EMR added to was to our abilities under both the Customs Act and the Immigration Refugee Protection Act for a new prohibition on entry.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. But the Immigration Refugee Protection Act would -- it does set out admissibility/inadmissibility ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- criteria; right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And if somebody went to the border and there was reasonable grounds or they were suspected to go -- wanted to be admitted to Canada to engage in unlawful activity, would that be sufficient basis to turn them away?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Certainly, if the officer felt that they weren't here for a lawful you could turn them away.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: But -- if someone, you know, showed up at the border today and said "I want to come to Ottawa to protest something" that's not a reason to prohibit their entry if they're otherwise admissible.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So the issue -- the legislative gap was specific to turning foreign nationals away who wanted to participate in a lawful, peaceful protest?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: In an unlawful protest. In a -- what was defined in the Act as a prohibited protest I believe is the language.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And -- so I guess what I'm getting at is it seems like the Immigration Refugee Protection Act would have already given the CBSA that power at the point in which the protests were deemed to have been unlawful.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Not specifically, because it wasn't a specific prohibition on entry into the country.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: What do you mean by that?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: It -- it's not -- it wasn't part of -- there are tools that were available to officers to exercise. So we don't know where you're going to go once you come in.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. But if there were reasonable grounds or there was a suspicion that that was there, and destination, then that would be a sufficient basis to turn them away?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, but you're assuming that they're going to tell us the truth about where they're going.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. And I mean, border services officers are trained to assess whether somebody is telling the truth or not?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So you talked briefly about how a lot of foreign nationals were turned away because they didn't meet the requirements under the Quarantine Act if they weren't vaccinated, for example, and my counsel -- my co-counsel will get into this further, so I'll leave that to him. But I guess my question is whether that was sufficient to attenuate CBSA's concerns that foreign nationals were entering to participate in the protest, the idea that they would most likely be turned away pursuant to the Quarantine Act requirements?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, as I said, yeah, I think it was -- we were fortunate in that we had these other prohibitions on entry at play to prevent people from coming in and participating, but there were people that came in that met all the requirements and could have gone to the protest.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. Okay, thank you. So I only have about five minutes left before I'm going to turn it over to Mr. Cameron, so I just want to pull up one last document. And that's, Mr. Clerk, COM00000670. So this is the government's section 58 explanation. Are you familiar with this document?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Did you have any role in drafting it?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I think we might have given some factual inputs that were used later on in the document with respect to sort of the situation at the border.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. So inputs, but you didn't hold the pen?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No, absolutely not.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right. So if we go to page 7. Yeah, right there. So just a little bit up, just where it says, "In addition". So it says -- it describes two events where it's -- that occurred, one at the Pacific Highway port of entry, and one in Fort Erie, and it says that at those two locations: "...protesters had breached the confines of the CBSA plaza resulting in CBSA officers..."
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Could you slow down, please?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Thank you, Mr. Commissioner: "...locking down the office to prevent additional protesters from gaining entry." So the event at Fort Erie happened on the 12th; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And according to a situational report, it was 120 vehicles that converged on -- in the area of the Peace Bridge; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And protesters accessed the CBSA plaza, which I understand to mean sort of the parking lot - --
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes, the buildings, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- on foot. And then it says that police and the CBSA were able to direct the protesters to leave after 20 minutes. Is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Well, the officers, in the case of Fort Erie, locked down the building because they were trying to get access to the building, and I think the building was locked down for 12 hours. And I would just actually make a correction here that at Pacific Highway, there was a vehicle that you may recall there was pictures of in the media that had sort of military camouflage paint that breached a barrier, but I don't believe that they actually locked down the building in the Pacific Highway region.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Right, and we have evidence from Dwayne McDonald who’s the Commander for the “E” Division of the RCMP and he describes the event, basically, as a -- exactly as you’ve just put it, so that there was sort of a painted vehicle that crossed a threshold but it wasn’t a breach, per se.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And he also observed that the media reports on that specific event were not accurate; would you agree with that?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I couldn’t speculate without reading them, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. Do you have any doubt to -- any reason to doubt his evidence?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And just for the record, I’ll note that that’s WTS00000069 at page 20, which is the RCMP Panel Witness Summary, and Dwayne McDonald’s evidence is in there. So my last question for you before I turn it over to my colleague is that the Section 58 explanation also talks broadly about the economic impacts of the border blockades, and I understand that CBSA itself did not conduct any analysis on the economic impacts; is that right?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: That’s correct. We just simply track the number of conveyances that cross the border and, as well, we do something else called “value-for-duty”, but that’s -- wouldn’t be used for and kind of real economic value impact analysis.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. Did you say “value- for-duty”?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. And who did you provide that data to?
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: All of that data is provided as a matter of course to other government departments, Department of Finance, Statistics Canada, other entities that sort of track these types of things.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And so they would have, then, undertaken the economic analysis ---
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: I assume so.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- based on your data you send them? Okay. Okay, thank you so much, Mr. Ossowski. Those are all of my questions. I’m going to pass it over to Mr. Cameron now.
speaker: MS. ALEXANDRA HEINE

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON:
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning, sir. My name’s Gordon Cameron. I have just a few questions to finish off your examination by Commission counsel this morning. Let me begin, just so that I don’t get it wrong for the whole examination that I did, do you prefer Ossowski or Ossowski?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: Ossowski.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Ossowski, thank you. And I’ll apologize if I speak in the present tense because I acknowledge you’ve since retired. So if I talk to you as if you’re still in charge of CBSA, just ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: I still feel like I am.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Yeah, just make the time change on my behalf. But certainly, when you were at CBSA, CBSA had, and you would have had overall responsibility as its president or deputy minister, the Intelligence and Enforcement Branch?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And am I correct -- I’m just going by website information, so if I get it wrong, please correct me -- that Ted Gallivan, as executive vice president, would have had that under his purview as well?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: No, at the time, it would have been Vice President Scott Harris that was in charge of the Intelligence and Enforcement Branch.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Thank you. And tell me briefly why CBSA has an Intelligence and Enforcement Branch.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: So what that branch was responsible for is giving the frontline the situational awareness in terms of targeting, for example -- so we have a targeting centre -- and where we do -- and try to add value to officers on the frontline in terms of things that they need to be aware of. So, for example, if law enforcement partners want lookouts on the system, they’re the ones that would sort of manage that type of thing. If somebody’s of interest coming into the country or leaving the country, all -- they would be the relationship lead with all of the other national security partners on intelligence that would be important in terms of the day-to-day functioning of the border. They’re also responsible for the removals of the people that are found to be inadmissible to Canada after they’ve gone through due process. So it’s a complicated job.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And it’s a fairly substantial department within CBSA?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: The branch?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Yes.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: Yes, it is.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And they produce what we’ve learned to call “intelligence products” for use by CBSA management and personnel?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: Well, they -- I would say that in term of the national security apparatus, we’re largely a consumer of intelligence, so they would do, as I said, the liaising with other partners domestically and abroad to create products that would be useful to the frontline in terms of how they’re managing the border on a day-to-day basis.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Fair enough. So they would take in information and distill from it the information that’s most likely relevant to ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: --- CBSA’s mandate and then distribute within the organization?
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: Correct.
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Thank you. And it seems, just by instinct, that the two concerns here will be using that intelligence and those assessments to protect the security of Canada in terms of people who might be coming into the country and to protect your personnel who have to deal with these situations on the frontline; is that ---
section_header: EXAMINATION IN-CHIEF BY MR. GORDON CAMERON
speaker: MR. GORDON CAMERON

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And the Canadian subsidiary is the Canadian Transit Company; correct?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Does the Canadian Transit Company own the land around the bridge infrastructure and the structures housing the CBSA?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I believe so, and it’s provided to us under Section 6 of the Customs Act ---
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay.
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: --- for us to use that facility.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Are there any other international border crossings managed by the CBSA that are owned and operated by a private corporation?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Several. Yes, there’s several, what we call, Section 6 operators that provide us the facilities in order for them to provide that availability for travellers and commercial vehicles to cross. So the Peace Bridge, for example, is another example of that.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. I take it, Mr. Ossowski, that you are familiar with Windsor and the location of the Ambassador Bridge?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I am.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: The Ambassador Bridge sits at one end of a municipal roadway, Huron Church Road; correct?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.

text_clean_combined: And that road about three kilometres or so from the provincial highway?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: So truck drivers have to contend, Mayor Dilkens testified, six or seven local intersections with traffic as they move along Huron Church Road to and from the bridge?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Is this unique, in particular, with respect to points of entry geared towards commercial conveyances?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I wouldn’t say it’s unique but I would say that there’s -- every port of entry is different in terms of the infrastructure leading to and from them, but that is a different situation, for sure.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. And the road is surrounded by residential areas on both sides, educational institutions, and businesses?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: The University of Windsor is right beside the bridge and the CBSA facilities; correct?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I believe so, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And you’ll agree that Huron Church bisects the city, so serving as an assess point between the east and west sides of Windsor?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: And are you aware that the route under the bridge along Huron Church is an important route connecting West Windsor to downtown?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I’m familiar with that particular route.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. So the thousands of trucks that cross the border every day share Huron Church Road with local Windsor residents?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Mayor Dilkens of Windsor testified last week in response to a question from Commission counsel who asked whether or not there was any discussion about trying to prevent the blockade, and Mayor Dilkens testified that because of the distance between the Ambassador Bridge and the highway, and the number of businesses, homes, hotels, and schools that require direct access to Huron Church Road, he said that it would be, for all intents and purposes, practically impossible to guarantee with any certainty that you could provide a route for trucks without having huge disruption to the community. Would you agree with Mayor Dilkens?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I agree. And in fact, there was a fair bit of activity after the bridge reopened to put Jersey barriers up there to make sure that other protests didn’t manifest along those intersections.

text_clean_combined: Okay. Well, if I can just ask -- I wanted to ask you few questions about that. If Mr. Clerk could please pull up SSM.NSC.CAN00000340_REL.0001. text_clean_combined: Okay. I have a few questions about -- just to clarify the impact of border blockades on other border crossings. Mr. Clerk, you can take down that document. So the CBSA Ambassador Bridge Operations is also responsible for the Windsor Truck Ferry; right?

text_clean_combined: Okay. You spoke this morning about the impact of the Ambassador Bridge blockade and the Blue Water Bridge and some of the other bridges. Did the slow rolls and blockades of other border crossings like Blue Water impact traffic at the Ambassador Bridge?

And so if there was a disruption or a planned disruption, then we would try and reallocate officers and/or provide situational awareness to our American counterparts to make sure that we could manage whatever flows might materialize. text_clean_combined: And at that time, were there slow rolls also at the Ambassador Bridge?

text_clean_combined: Again, I’d have to go back and look at the reports, but yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. But certainly, slow rolls and blockades of any of the bridges in Southern Ontario will impact the use of the neighbouring bridges?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Absolutely.

text_clean_combined: Okay. I have a few questions just to clarify the CBSA’s authorities at and near ports of entry.

text_clean_combined: Sure.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Yeah, so we have limited -- our authorities are limited, generally, the arrest authorities under the Criminal Code for what happens to -- under the Customs Act, sorry, and the Immigration Refugee Protection Act. So an example might be if we would detain somebody that is suspected of drinking and driving or drinking under the influence, then we would call local law enforcement and then they would proceed with whatever criminal charges of that. So we’re circumscribed through the Customs Act and the Immigration and Refugee Protections Act.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: CBSA officers, do they have the authority to arrest under the Criminal Code?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Only with -- I’d have to defer to the lawyers, but I believe that it’s only with respect to the Customs Act and the Immigration and Refugee Protections Act.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. So they don’t have the authority to enforce, for example, a breach of a court order under the Criminal Code?

text_clean_combined: So if we could look at SSM.NSC.CAN0000340_Rel.0001? This is back to your briefing material. And if you could go to page 5, please? text_clean_combined: And that’s your understanding?

speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.

speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: That’s correct.

text_clean_combined: Yes.

text_clean_combined: I’m reading it as you’re telling me this. Yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. And Mr. Keenan refers to the federal authorities under the Customs Act and the International Bridges and Tunnels Act, but concludes that these Acts don’t: “….directly bring any authorities to bear on the blockade…” Right?

text_clean_combined: That’s what it appears to be, yeah.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. And do you agree with Michael Keenan’s email?

text_clean_combined: I do.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: All right. Thank you, Mr. Clerk. Mr. Ossowski, you understand that Windsor and other municipalities were challenged in terms of their capacity to respond to these protests, in terms of the availability of local policing and other resources, such as in Windsor’s case, jersey barriers?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I do.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Would you agree that bolstering local capacity and resources is necessary to mitigate the risk of major impacts on the operation of the federal border crossings in the future?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I think that would apply to many ports of entry that saw disruptions like this, based on their unique geography and/or access routes to and from the ports of entry, yes.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Would you agree that the blockades revealed a mismatch between jurisdictional authorities and responsibilities?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I think we saw that across the entire country, and I think that, you know, from my perspective of trying to run the border in a nationally consistent manner, and seeing the variations in response across the country, either how law enforcement chose to respond to it, or what the particular infrastructure was, was problematic for us.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. Mr. Commissioner, I know I’m at the end of my time. I just have a couple more questions.
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: You’re actually over your time, but please wrap up as quickly as possible.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Mr. Ossowski, Mayor Dilkens of Windsor, we’ve heard that he wrote to the Ontario and Federal Governments in March earlier this year and he stated that following the blockades, the need for broader collaboration and support, and I think in this case he meant of local authorities, from Provincial and Federal Governments to bolster the safety and security of our borders appears obvious. Do you agree with Mayor Dilkens?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: I agree.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. And given the particular jurisdictional issues surrounding international bridges, like those in Windsor, and the evidence that you’ve already given, would you agree that a specific plan should be developed by all three levels of government for international border crossings?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: If I were to be so bold as to offer a potential recommendation of the Commission is, is that I think that that is something that should be done, and as well, in terms of how police of jurisdiction choose to respond to something like this should be exercised regularly so that this type of thing doesn’t, you know, take root and be so hard to disentangle, as was the case in January and February.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Okay. And my final question, Mr. Ossowski, and thank you, Mr. Commissioner, for this indulgence, would you agree then that coordination across all three levels of government, including the coordination of responsibilities and responsibility for costs should be part of that plan?
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Well I can’t speak to costs, but I can certainly speak to coordination of responsibilities would make it a lot easier, I think, for all parties to manage these situations in the future.
speaker: MR. JOHN OSSOWSKI

text_clean_combined: Thank you. Those are my questions.
speaker: MS. JENNIFER KING

text_clean_combined: Okay. Thank you. And next I’d like to call on the Government of Alberta.
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU
